Enablers and inhibitors of research integrity


UKCORI presents a study exploring the evidence for systemic factors that may enable or inhibit research integrity.


 




Ethics guidelines for internet-mediated research


This document presents guidance on how the British Psychological Society code may be interpreted in the context of Internet-mediated research (IMR) and what special considerations may apply.

title: Guidance for researchers using social media for recruitment
text: Advice for researchers who are planning to recruit participants via social media when planning, writing and submitting their application to the School Research Ethics Committee (SREC)

title: Social Media Research: A Guide to Ethics
text: This document is intended for use by researchers, students, members of ethics committees, employees of funding bodies, and anyone else with an interest in the ethics of working with social media data. The main purpose of the document is to provide clear guidelines on the ethical use of social media data in research.

title: Enablers and inhibitors of research integrity
Exploring indicators of research integrity
text:
UKCORI presents their work on the development of indicators of research integrity for use by Higher Education Institutions (HEIs) in the UK to: (1) build the evidence base for research integrity on a UK-wide scale, and (2) support HEIs to self-assess and improve their support for research integrity.
Website

title: UKRIO
text: The UK Research Integrity Office (UKRIO) is an independent charity, offering support to the public, researchers and organisations to further good practice in academic, scientific and medical research.

title: UKCORI
text:
The UK Committee on Research Integrity (UKCORI) promotes and drives research integrity in the UK.
Their vision is that the UK’s research system continues to be known for its research integrity, which:

is central to the work and actions of all individuals, groups, and organisations in the research system

enhances and protects the quality of research

safeguards confidence in research

They work across the research system, including:

higher education institutions

independent research organisations
research institutes

research funders
public, private and third sector organisations

title: UKRN
text: The UK Reproducibility Network (UKRN) is a national peer-led consortium that aims to ensure the UK retains its place as a centre for world-leading research by investigating the factors that contribute to robust research, promoting training activities, and disseminating best practice. They also work collaboratively with various external stakeholders to ensure coordination of efforts across the sector.

title: Scottish Research Integrity Network
text:
The Scottish Research Integrity Network is a member-led forum founded in November 2019 with the aim of sharing excellence, good practice and expertise in the field of research integrity across all research active institutions in Scotland. We currently number over sixty members, drawn from research, teaching and professional services backgrounds at some twenty Scottish universities, research institutes and funding bodies. The purpose of our submission is to draw attention to the role of grassroots networks in the research and innovation sector in responding to challenges to the integrity of research.
